document_text: ADMISSION NOTE - Date: 2024-08-15. Patient: Jane M. Thompson, DOB: 1956-03-22, MRN: 4478291. Chief complaint: Acute onset chest pain radiating to left arm for 2 hours. History: 68-year-old female with hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and hyperlipidemia presented to the ED with substernal chest pain rated 8/10, associated with diaphoresis and nausea. ECG showed ST elevation in leads V1-V4. Troponin I elevated at 4.8 ng/mL. Aspirin 325 mg and heparin drip initiated. Cardiology consulted for emergent cardiac catheterization. Admitting physician: Dr. Robert Chen, Cardiology.

extracted.chief_complaint: Acute onset chest pain radiating to left arm

document_text: DISCHARGE SUMMARY - Discharge Date: 2024-09-03. Patient: Michael R. Davis, MRN: 5523180. Admission Date: 2024-08-28. Principal Diagnosis: Community-acquired pneumonia, right lower lobe. Secondary Diagnoses: COPD exacerbation, acute kidney injury (resolved). Hospital Course: The patient was admitted with fever of 102.4F, productive cough, and hypoxia requiring 4L nasal cannula. Chest X-ray confirmed right lower lobe consolidation. Treated with IV ceftriaxone and azithromycin, transitioned to oral amoxicillin-clavulanate on day 4. Oxygen weaned to room air by day 5. Creatinine normalized from 2.1 to 1.0. Discharge disposition: Home with home health services. Follow-up: PCP in 7 days, pulmonology in 4 weeks.

LABORATORY REPORT - Date: 2024-07-20. Patient: Sarah L. Kim, DOB: 1989-11-08, MRN: 6691045. Ordering Physician: Dr. Amanda Foster, Internal Medicine. Test Panel: Comprehensive Metabolic Panel. Results: Glucose 142 mg/dL (H), BUN 28 mg/dL (H), Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL (H), Sodium 136 mEq/L, Potassium 5.2 mEq/L (H), Chloride 101 mEq/L, CO2 22 mEq/L, Calcium 9.8 mg/dL, Total Protein 7.1 g/dL, Albumin 3.8 g/dL, Bilirubin Total 0.9 mg/dL, Alkaline Phosphatase 85 U/L, AST 24 U/L, ALT 31 U/L. Interpretation: Elevated glucose, BUN, creatinine, and potassium. Recommend correlation with clinical history.

OPERATIVE REPORT - Date: 2024-09-18. Patient: Catherine E. Brown, MRN: 7734562. Surgeon: Dr. James Wilson, Orthopedic Surgery. Assistant: Dr. Maria Santos. Procedure: Right total knee arthroplasty. Anesthesia: Spinal with sedation. Preoperative Diagnosis: Severe tricompartmental osteoarthritis, right knee. The patient was positioned supine on the operating table. A standard midline incision was made and a medial parapatellar arthrotomy performed. Severe tricompartmental degenerative changes were confirmed. The distal femur and proximal tibia were prepared with standard cuts. A size 5 femoral component and size 4 tibial component with a 10 mm polyethylene insert were cemented in place. The patella was resurfaced with a 32 mm all-polyethylene component. Range of motion 0-120 degrees achieved. Estimated blood loss: 250 mL. No complications.

CONSULTATION NOTE - Date: 2024-08-22. Patient: David A. Nguyen, DOB: 1960-02-17, MRN: 8845673. Requesting Physician: Dr. Helen Park, Internal Medicine. Consulting Physician: Dr. Steven Martinez, Gastroenterology. Reason for Consultation: Abnormal liver function tests and new-onset ascites. History: 64-year-old male with a 30-year history of alcohol use (6-8 drinks daily), presenting with 3 weeks of progressive abdominal distention. Labs notable for AST 156 U/L, ALT 78 U/L, total bilirubin 3.4 mg/dL, albumin 2.6 g/dL, INR 1.8, platelets 89K. Abdominal ultrasound shows a nodular liver with large-volume ascites. Assessment: Probable decompensated alcoholic cirrhosis with new-onset ascites. Plan: Diagnostic paracentesis today, start spironolactone and furosemide, initiate hepatology referral for transplant evaluation.

extracted.reason_for_consultation: Abnormal liver function tests and new-onset ascites

document_text: NURSING ASSESSMENT - Date: 2024-10-12, Time: 0730. Patient: Robert K. Patel, MRN: 3356789, Room: 4-215B. Vital Signs: BP 158/92 mmHg, HR 88 bpm, RR 20, Temp 98.6F, SpO2 94% on 2L NC. Pain: 6/10 in right hip, described as aching and constant. Neurological: Alert and oriented x4, pupils equal and reactive. Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs. Respiratory: Diminished breath sounds bilateral bases, productive cough with clear sputum. GI: Abdomen soft, bowel sounds present, tolerating regular diet. Skin: Stage 2 pressure injury on sacrum measuring 2.5 x 1.8 cm, wound bed 80% granulation with mild serous drainage. Foley catheter in place with 350 mL clear yellow urine output over past 8 hours. Fall risk: High (Morse score 65). Plan: Continue current medications, reposition every 2 hours, wound care per protocol.

extracted.wound_status: Stage 2 pressure injury, sacrum, 2.5 x 1.8 cm, 80% granulation
